item.title: String Theory: Physics' Forty-Year Con Job
item.description:
They sold us eleven dimensions and delivered zero predictions. Welcome to the greatest intellectual pyramid scheme in physics history, where mathematical beauty became the excuse for scientific bankruptcy, and two generations of brilliant physicists got eaten alive by a framework that can’t be tested, can’t be falsified, and somehow — SOMEHOW — keeps getting funding.

Forty years. Forty years of conferences and textbooks and tenure committees selecting for string theory fluency. What did we get? Ten to the power of 500 possible universes. That’s not a Theory of Everything. That’s a confession that you have no fucking idea what’s happening, written in sufficiently exotic notation that you need a PhD to recognize the confession.

item.title: What Happens When You Look
item.description:
Quantum mechanics is the most accurate scientific theory in human history. The Dirac equation predicts the magnetic moment of the electron to 12 decimal places. The Standard Model has been confirmed to parts per trillion. No theory has been more precisely validated by experiment.

None of this tells you what happens when you look.

The wavefunction collapse problem – what occurs when a quantum system is measured – has been unresolved since Heisenberg in 1927. Not unresolved as in “partially understood, more work needed.” Unresolved as in: physicists actively disagree about whether anything happens at all, whether the word “happens” is even applicable, and whether asking the question constitutes legitimate physics or the kind of philosophy they agreed to stop doing.
